data.title: Costa Book Awards: Women dominate UK shortlist for 2016
data.meta_description: Three previous winners are in the running for the prestigious book of the year - Maggie O'Farrell, Sarah Perry and Rose Tremain.
data.text:
Nominees for this year's Costa Book Awards have been revealed, with female writers dominating UK's "most outstanding books".

Maggie O'Farrell, Sarah Perry and Rose Tremain are three of the 14 women tipped to win the coveted £30,000 book of the year prize.

The 2016 shortlist chose 20 from 596 entries across five categories - including first novel, novel, biography, poetry and children's book.

The winner of each category takes home £5,000 and is automatically shortlisted for the coveted book of the year title.

"I think it's great to see so many female authors shortlisted," Irish-Caribean author Kit de Waal told Sky News.

"Sometimes women in the arts are underrepresented, and hopefully this bring light to the fact that there are a number of talented women within the industry."

De Waal was nominated for the First Novel Award for My Name Is Leon - "a heart-breaking story of love, identity and learning to overcome unbearable loss".

This year's Poetry Award is an all-female ensemble, with rapper/novelist Kate Tempest tipped for Let Them Eat Chaos - a long poem written for live performance and released with an album of the same name.

The judges in this year's panel - which include writers Nicci Gerrard and Andrew O'Hagan - called the book "magical, indispensable, wonderful - a cry from the heart to a wounded world".

The 30-year old artist won the Ted Hughes Award in 2013 for her work Brand New Ancients and was nominated for a Mercury Music Prize for her debut album Everybody Down.

The Costa Book Awards is the only major UK book prize open solely to authors resident in the UK and Ireland.

Originally established in 1971 as the Whitbread Awards, it recognises "the most outstanding and enjoyable" books published the previous year.

Three previous prize winners have been shortlisted for this year's Novel Award.

Sebastian Barry, whose book The Secret Sculpture won book of the year in 2008, is nominated for his 2015 entry Days Without End.

The novel follows the adventures of two teenage brothers who sign up with the US army to fight in the Indian wars, finding beauty and wonder among the horrors of battle.

Essex native Maggie O'Farrell, who took home 2010's Best Novel with The Hand That First Held Mine, is now nominated for This Must Be The Place.

"An utterly involving read, both funny and heartbreaking - technically dazzling, but never losing its human touch," the judges said.

Booker shortlist and CBE Rose Tremain is no stranger to Costa either - her book Music and Silence took home the Novel Award in 1999.

Her latest novel, The Gustav Sonata, has been described as "a deft, delicate and vivid book in three movements - pitch perfect and humane".

Last year's book of the year award went to The Lie Tree by Frances Hardinge.

Winners of the five categories will be announced on 3 January, 2017.

The overall Book Of The Year Award will be presented at the Costa Book Awards ceremony in central London on 31 January, 2017.
